page.title: Quantifiers and QP
page.introduction:
Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase. Most languages have four sets of quantifiers:
Those meaning all or not, which modify the whole nominal phrase,
quantifiers such as some or no, which do not co-occur with any other modifers except adjectives,
other quantifiers such as many or few, and
numbers.
We'll deal with each in turn.

Quantifiers meaning all or not seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last), in a position distinct from the other quantifiers, but in the same place as degree words like only and just (which can also acts as focus markers to be dscussed in
Focus and Topic Constructions) and words that mean the same as almost (which can also co-occur with all as in (4) below), so we will refer to them as special degree words.
page.instruction: Look for examples in your language like the following:
Note that not can occur in place of or before these other special degree words:

Be sure to distinguish elements like not which may negate a fully modified nominal phrase from words like no (to be treated on the next page) which take the place of any articles, demonstratives and possessors in the phrase.

form.prompt: Key the way your language expresses "all", with each word followed by a period and on a separate line. (If "all" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

Key the way your language expresses "almost", with each word followed by a period and on a separate line. (If "almost" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

Key the way your language expresses "only" or "just". (If either is an affix or clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

Key the way your language expresses "not" (when it modifies a nominal rather than a verbal phrase), with each word followed by a period and on a separate line. (If "not" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language express these concepts as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they are all separate words
The positive ones (especially 'all') are separate words, but 'not' attaches to another word
The positive ones (especially 'all') are separate words, but there is not any way to express 'not' modifying a nominal phrase in the language
The negative word for 'not' is a separate word, but the positive ones (especially 'all') attach to another word
No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase
No, the positive ones (especially 'all') attach to another word in the nominal phrase, but there is not any way to express 'not' modifying a nominal phrase in the language

radioGroup.prompt: Where do the positive special degree elements (especially 'all') attach within the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: As a phrasal proclitic which attaches to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase
As a phrasal enclitic which attaches to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase

Some forms are phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase and others are phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase
As a prefix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
As a suffix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
Some forms are prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase and some forms are suffixes

radioGroup.prompt: Where do the negative special degree elements attach within the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: As a phrasal proclitic which attaches to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase
As a phrasal enclitic which attaches to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase

Some forms are phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase and others are phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase
As a prefix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
As a suffix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
Some forms are prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase and some forms are suffixes

form.prompt: Key your examples of the positive words affixes clitics meaning 'all', 'almost' and 'only' or 'just' included in full nominal phrases here:
Key your examples of the negative words affixes clitics meaning 'not' included in full nominal phrases (without the positive special degree elements) here:

radioGroup.prompt: Looking at the data in the two boxes box above, where do these special degree elements which are written as separate words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the special degree words appear on either side of the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Can the word(s) meaning 'not' co-occur with the other special degree words?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No

form.prompt: Key your examples of the word(s) clitic(s) affix(es) meaning 'not' in full nominal phrases including the positive special degree elements here:

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the word or words meaning 'not' occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase (including the other special degree word(s)?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the special degree words meaning 'not' appear on either side of the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction (or only one word that can appear either place)
No, there are separate sets for each side

form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark the words meaning all, not, almost, only, and just with the features makeDeg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to Deg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs. If your language has a phrase meaning almost, such as not quite or just about, you need to make a single entry for these phrases with an underscore (_) between them and run the Join Compound program before AMPLE. These entries need the same features as a single word entry with a similar meaning would have.
Also, mark the word or words meaning all with the features plural quantifier and mark the word or words meaning not with the feature negative. These negative words will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the words meaning all, almost, only, and just with the features makeDeg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to Deg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs. If your language has a phrase meaning almost, such as just about, you need to make a single entry for these phrases with an underscore (_) between them and run the Join Compound program before AMPLE. These entries need the same features as a single word entry with a similar meaning would have.
Also, mark the word or words meaning all with the features plural quantifier.

In the lexicon, mark the words meaning not with the features Deg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to makeDeg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs.
Also, mark the word or words meaning not with the feature negative. These negative words will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.
In the lexicon, mark the positive proclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_prefix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive enclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive proclitics meaning all with the features plural quantifier_prefix and the positive enclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive prefix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.
In the lexicon, mark the positive suffix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.
In the lexicon, mark the positive prefix(es) and suffix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.

In the lexicon, mark the negative proclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_prefix. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the negative enclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_suffix. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the negative proclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_prefix and the negative enclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_suffix. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the negative prefix(es) meaning not with the feature negative. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the negative suffix(es) meaning not with the feature negative. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark the negative prefix(es) and suffix(es) meaning not with the feature negative. These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negation Constructions.

In the lexicon, mark those special degree words which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any special degree words which can occur on either side.

In the lexicon, mark the special degree words meaning not which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any special degree words which can occur on either side.
